 Back when you and I used to argue about the 14th amendment and the 9th amendment, I learned a lot from you and was inspired to read more and think more about these amendments. I also came to think that anyone who wants to understand constitutional interpretation has to take seriously the interpretive philosophy and approach of Justice Scalia (and others who agree with him). 
 
 I continue to think that the 14th amendment changed fundamentally the role of the federal government. Specifically, the 14th made the federal government the protector of individual rights against state abrogation, which had not been its role previously. Before the 14th, the federal government had been generally viewed as the source of power that threatened liberty. With the ratification of the 14th amendment, the federal government became the protector of liberty from state power. I think if you use the "original meaning" approach of Justice Scalia, you come to that conclusion about the 14th (though I don't think Justice Scalia has come to that conclusion). 
 
 The knotty questions about the 14th amendment continue to revolve around what specific rights the amendment protects. My reading of John Bingham suggests that he intended not only to incorporate the Bill of Rights and apply those rights to the states (through the privileges or immunities clause), but also to use federal power to protect rights not specifically enumerated in the Bill of Rights. Bingham took a broad view of the rights that he thought the constitution protects. I think Thaddeus Stevens probably had a similar view, though I need to research this. 
 
 Anyhow, the equal protection clause is among the most difficult to address, because what the framers/ratifiers/rational people at the time thought it should mean is not clear from the historical evidence.
